file_name: Yang 等 - 2021 - A cooperative driving framework for urban arterials in mixed traffic conditions.pdf

structured_info.title_cn: 混合交通条件下城市主干道协同驾驶框架
structured_info.title_en: A cooperative driving framework for urban arterials in mixed traffic conditions
structured_info.abstract: Enabling technologies of connected and automated vehicles (CAVs) bring new opportunities to signalized intersection control. This study proposes a hierarchical and implementation-ready cooperative driving framework with a mixed traffic composition of CAVs, connected vehicles (CVs), and regular vehicles (RVs) for urban arterials. The proposed framework combines centralized and distributed control concepts, where the infrastructure generates optimal signal timing plans and provides high-level trajectory guidance to the CAVs while detailed trajectories are generated by each vehicle. The system consists of three levels: vehicle-level state transition diagrams for CAV operations, intersection-level mixed-integer linear programming (MILP) for signal and arrival time optimization, and corridor-level linear programming (LP) for offset optimization. Simulation results from a real-world arterial corridor show reduced delays (2.2-33.0%) and fuel consumption (3.9-7.4%) across different CAV penetration rates.
structured_info.methodology: Hierarchical framework combining: 1) Vehicle-level state transition diagrams for CAV operations (eco-trajectory planning, CACC platooning, collision avoidance), 2) Intersection-level MILP optimizing signal timing and CAV arrival times, 3) Corridor-level LP for dynamic offset optimization using link performance functions.
structured_info.conclusion: The framework reduces total delay by 2.2-33.0% and fuel consumption by 3.9-7.4% across CAV penetration rates. Benefits increase with higher CAV adoption. Dynamic offset optimization accommodates volume fluctuations, improving mobility and fuel economy. The implementation-ready design works with existing infrastructure and partial CAV deployment.
structured_info.venue: Transportation Research Part C: Emerging Technologies

analysis.Overview: Proposes a hierarchical cooperative driving framework for urban arterials combining infrastructure-based signal optimization with vehicle-level trajectory control in mixed traffic environments (CAVs, CVs, RVs). Focuses on reducing delays and fuel consumption through coordinated control across vehicle, intersection, and corridor levels.
Background_and_Motivation: Urban signalized intersections are traffic bottlenecks; CAV technologies enable new data sources and control opportunities.
Existing studies assume 100% CAV environments or lack corridor-level coordination, limiting real-world applicability during the long transition to full automation.
Argues current infrastructure (e.g., loop detectors) and partial CAV penetration require flexible solutions without heavy computational investments.
Relates specific problem of arterial inefficiency to broader challenges of sustainable urban mobility and energy consumption.
Contributes to transportation engineering, control systems, and intelligent infrastructure fields.
Conceptual_Framework_and_Innovations: Cooperative Driving: Integration of infrastructure guidance (signal timing, high-level trajectories) with decentralized vehicle control (detailed trajectory generation).
Hierarchical Control: Three-tier structure (vehicle-intersection-corridor) distributing computational complexity.
Mixed Traffic Handling: Explicit modeling of interactions between CAVs, CVs (connected human-driven), and RVs (regular vehicles).

Infrastructure provides corridor-level offsets and intersection-level arrival targets → Vehicles generate trajectories incorporating eco-driving, platooning, and safety constraints → Optimized traffic flow emerges from coordination.
Implicitly assumes reliable V2X communication, accurate traffic state estimation, and CAV compliance with infrastructure guidance.
Provides methodological innovation through hierarchical decomposition and practical implementation framework for partial automation.
Methodology: Combines MILP (signal/arrival optimization), LP (offset optimization), trigonometric trajectory planning, and state-based vehicle controllers.
Novelty: First corridor-level coordination for mixed traffic. Applicable to current infrastructure; rational through real-time computational feasibility demonstrated.
Uses loop detector data and V2X communication (BSMs). Data preprocessed via shockwave models for queue prediction. Representativeness validated through calibrated real-world simulations.
Rigorous experimental design: VISSIM simulations with MOVES fuel model, 5 random seeds, sensitivity analysis. Metrics: delay, stops, fuel consumption.
Follows systems optimization paradigm, integrating traffic flow theory with control systems for holistic perspective.
Results: Delay reductions: 14% (CV-only) to 33% (100% CAV); Fuel savings: 3.8% (RV estimation) to 7.4% (full CAV). Dynamic offsets further reduce delays by 5.3% under 10% volume fluctuations.
Results show statistical significance across penetration rates. Stability confirmed via sensitivity analyses; benefits scale reliably with CAV adoption.
Argumentation_and_Logic: Structured: Problem limitations → Framework design → Component details → Validation → Implications.
1) Identify gaps (100% CAV assumption, no corridor coordination) 2) Propose hierarchical solution 3) Validate via simulation 4) Quantify benefits.
Strengths: Clear causal chain from design to outcomes. Addresses rebuttals (e.g., computational burden) via distributed computation. Weakness: Limited discussion of communication failures.
Strengths_and_Limitations: Strengths: Implementation-ready design, two-way corridor coordination, validation under partial CAV penetration, computational efficiency.
Limitations: Assumes perfect perception/compliance; no lateral control; RV state estimation errors reduce benefits.
Optimization paradigm prioritizes efficiency over robustness, constraining conclusions to nominal operating conditions.
Academic_Discourse_and_Rhetoric: Positions as bridge between isolated-intersection studies and full autonomy research, advancing mixed-traffic corridor management.
Technical terminology (e.g., CACC, MILP); persuasive tone emphasizing practicality; contrasts framework with 'limitations' of prior work.
Builds authority through 30+ citations aligning with transportation literature. Motivations: Establish solution viability for transitional automation phases.
Conclusions_and_Implications: Hierarchical cooperation significantly improves arterial performance. Benefits increase with CAV penetration and dynamic coordination.
Future work: Incorporate lateral control, network-level routing, robustness to communication failures, and field testing.
